semesters.name: PHY-201
semesters.description: University Physics I. Calculus based introductory physics: mechanics, heat, fluids, waves, with applicationsfrom the physical and life sciences.

semesters.name: PHY-105
semesters.description: College Physics I Lab. Laboritory course for PHY101 and PHY201

semesters.name: CIM-540
semesters.description: Creative Coding. This course will introduce students to the building blocks of creative coding within the visual and media environment.

semesters.name: MTH-309
semesters.description: Discrete Mathematics. Mathematical methods of Computer Science and Computer Engineering. Mathematical reasoning, sets, relations, functions, Boolean algebra, combinatorics, graphs.

semesters.name: CSC-120
semesters.description: Computer Science I w/ lab. History of computing. Fundamental programming constructs. Algorithms and problem solving. Object-oriented programming. Recursion.

semesters.name: PHY-202
semesters.description: University Physics II. Calculus based introductory physics: electromagnetism, optics, modern physics, with applications from the life sciences.

semesters.name: PHY-106
semesters.description: College Physics II Lab. Laboritory course for PHY101 and PHY201

semesters.name: MTH-224
semesters.description: Intro to Probability and Statistics. Probability distributions, random variables, expectation and variance, point estimation, interval estimation, testing of hypotheses, analysis of variance.

semesters.name: CSC-220
semesters.description: Computer Science II w/ lab. Common APls including list, priority queue, set, and map, and their efficient implementations in an object-oriented language using fundamental data structures. Sorting and other applications of recursion. Combining asymptotic analysis and experiments to extrapolate running times. Using APls in a software project.

semesters.name: CSC-314
semesters.description: Computer Organization and Architecture. Digital logic and digital systems. Machine level representation of data. Assembly level machine organization. Memory system organization and architecture. Interfacing and communication. Functional organization. Multiprocessing and alternative architectures.

semesters.name: I.
semesters.description: Independent Study with Professor Zevesuy Rodriguez. We work together to create museum/exhibit style displays like a sound based high striker game, and a Unity drawing app with the Leap Motion. This replaces CIM 111, which is an intro to web development course.

semesters.name: PHI-115
semesters.description: Social Ethics and Issues in Computing. History, social context and methods and tools of analysis. Professional and ethical responsibilities. Intellectual property. Privacy and civil liberties.

semesters.name: CSC-317
semesters.description: Data Structures and Algorithm Analysis. Basic algorithmic analysis. Algorithmic strategies. Fundamental computing algorithms. Distributed algorithms. Cryptographic algorithms. Geometric algorithms.

semesters.name: CSC-322
semesters.description: Systems Programming (C & UNIX). C programming: Program structure, core language elements, pointers. System tools for C programming. Programming for UNIX: The system call interface, interfaces to the internet. Scripting.

semesters.name: CSC-545
semesters.description: Intro to Artificial Intelligence. Search and constraint satisfaction. Knowledge representation and reasoning. Natural language processing. Machine learning and neural networks. Game theory. AI programming.

semesters.name: CIM-594
semesters.description: Front End Development. Use languages like Sass and Less to create beautiful front ends.

semesters.name: CIM-542
semesters.description: Physical Computing. This seminar will examine the differences and opportunities present, between a series of physical computing techniques and rapid prototyping.

semesters.name: IEN-505
semesters.description: Robotics. Fundamentals of robotics including kinematics and dynamics, trajectory planning, sensors and actuators, robotic vision, and case studies. Building your own robot is an integral part of hands-on laboratory exercises. Matlab controltoolbox and image analysis toolbox will be extensively used for design and analysis.

semesters.name: CSC-427
semesters.description: Theory of Computing. Sets, relations, and languages. Automata theory. Basic computability theory. Turing machines. The complexity classes P and NP.

semesters.name: CSC-419
semesters.description: Programming Languagues. Overview of programming languages. Fundamental issues in language design. Virtual machines. Introduction to language translation. Models of execution control. Declaration, modularity, and storage management. Programming language semantics. Programming paradigms.

semesters.name: CSC-431
semesters.description: Software Engineering. Software processes, requirements and specifications, design, validation, evolution. Project management, tools and environments. Foundations of human-computer interaction. Risks and liabilities of computer-based systems. Intellectual property.

semesters.name: CIM-211
semesters.description: Interactive Design. In this class students will familiarize themselves with the disciplines of user experience (UX) and interaction design (IxD) by understanding and learning how to apply creative and abstract thinking skills to facilitate communication through the design of interfaces that connect information, products, services, and space. Students will be taught to prototype rich interactive experiences and to assess ease of use, utility, perception of the value of the system, and efficiency in performing tasks.

semesters.name: MTH-210
semesters.description: Intro to Linear Algebra. Vectors, matrix algebra, systems of linear equations, and related geometry in Euclidean spaces. Fundamentals of vector spaces, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues, and eigenspaces.

semesters.name: CSC-424
semesters.description: Introduction to computer networks and network applications. The protocol stack. Routing, switching and bridging technologies. Models of network computing. Internet standards and protocols.

semesters.name: CSC-421
semesters.description: Computer Operating Systems. Process management. Scheduling and dispatch. Interprocess communication. Memory management. File systems. Device management.Security and protection. System programming for UNIX.

semesters.name: CSC-329
semesters.description: Intro to Game Programming. Fundamental programming issues in game design: Software design; Version control; Basic graphics; GUI programming. Large-scale game project: Team development of a functional game; Graphics and GUI component; Networking component; Core game engine.

semesters.name: CSC-529
semesters.description: Intro to Computer Graphics. Graphic systems. Graphic communication. Geometric modeling (2D and 3D representations). Rendering. Advanced techniques. Display and input devices. Software packages.

semesters.name: GSC-107
semesters.description: This course will explore the causes, effects and societal responses to disasters. We will look at a variety of natural hazards and related disasters including flooding, volcanoes, landslides, earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunami and drought. Using excerpted segments of "disaster films" in conjunction with scientific treatments, we can identify the causes, frequency, consequences, risks, and public perceptions of natural hazards.
